titleStmt.title: Correspondence from Edward F. Noyes, May 22, 1878

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

div1.p:
Legation of the United States.
Paris, May 22nd 1878.

On the 15th November 1876 M. Washburne notified the Duke Decazes that the Commercial Agency of the United States at Gaboon, Africa, had been abolished, Congress having made no appropriation for the salary of the Agent. Subsequently the Agency was reestablished, the former incumbent, M. Albert Bushnell, having asked to be appointed without salary. advises me that March 4th 1877, he received a despatch so informing him, and that his Commission would be duly forwarded; that he communicated
this despatch at the French Commandant at Gaboon and with his permission resumed the duties of Commercial Agent; that sometime afterward, he received his Commission, directly from the Department of State. With a despatch stating that, as he had already been recognized and had an exequatur from the French Government, it was deemed unnecessary to ask for another. By a communication now received from the Commercial Agency at Gaboon, I learn that the Admiral Commandant has notified the Vice-Commercial Agent, M. Murphy that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs at Paris having received no notice from the Legation of the United States
of the re-establisment of that Agency, the French Authorities would until further orders, consider the suppression of the Agency as definitive.

The Official Register of the Department of State, issued December 1877, gives the appointment of Albert Bushnell as Commercial Agent at Gaboon, Jan. 12, 1877, Confirming the statement of M. Bushnell himself above given.

In view of these facts, I have the honor to ask your Excellency: if no inconsistent with the rules of your Department, to waive the presentation of the Commission of M. Bushnell, and cause the necessary exequatur to be issued for his recognition in his
official capacity as Commercial Agent of the United States at Gaboon.
I avail myself of this occasion to renew to your Excellency the assurances of the distinguished consideration with which I have the honor to be.
